--- title: "My title" author: "My name" institute: "Simon Fraser University" format: html --- # Header 1 ## Header 2 Some text. ## Formatting {#sec-formatting} ::: aside Note that each header automatically creates an anchor, making it easy to link to specific sections of your documents. ::: Text can be rendered *in italic* or **in bold** as well as [underlined]{.underline}. You can use superscripts^2^, subscripts~test~, ~~strikethrough~~, and `inline code`. > This is a quote. ## Columns :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="30%"} You can create columns. ::: ::: {.column width="70%"} And you can set their respective width. ::: :::: ## Lists - Item 1 - Item 2 - Item 3 ## Ordered lists 1. Item 1 2. Item 2 3. Item 3 ## Images ![Example image](qmd_jupyter.png) ## Tables | Col 1 | Col 2 | Col 3 | |------ |-------|--------| | a | 1 | red | | b | 2 | orange | | c | 3 | yellow | :::{.callout-note} Tables can be fully customized (or you could use raw html). ::: ## Equations $$ \frac{\partial \mathrm C}{ \partial \mathrm t } + \frac{1}{2}\sigma^{2} \mathrm S^{2} \frac{\partial^{2} \mathrm C}{\partial \mathrm C^2} + \mathrm r \mathrm S \frac{\partial \mathrm C}{\partial \mathrm S}\ = \mathrm r \mathrm C $$ ## Cross-references See @sec-formatting. *Note that you can add bibliographies, flow charts, the equivalent of HTML "div", and just so much more. Remember that this is a tiny overview.* ## Let's try some code blocks now ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # This is a block that runs 2 + 3 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 5 ``` ::: ::: ::: aside Did you notice that the content of your code blocks can be copied with a click? Of course, this is customizable. ::: ```{.r} # This is a block that doesn't run 2 + 3 ``` ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` country var 1 Canada 2.9 2 USA 3.1 3 Mexico 4.5 ``` ::: ::: ## Plots ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} plot(cars) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](html_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=672} ::: :::
You can play with options to add a title: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} plot(cars) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Stopping distance as a function of speed in cars](html_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=672} ::: :::
You can have more complex multi-plot layouts: ::: {.cell layout-ncol="2"} ```{.r .cell-code} plot(cars) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Stopping distance as a function of speed in cars](html_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} plot(pressure) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Vapor pressure of mercury as a function of temperature](html_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-2.png){width=672} ::: ::: For those who have `ggplot2`[^1], you can try that too: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(ggplot2) ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) + geom_point(mapping = aes(color = class)) + geom_smooth() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` `geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula = 'y ~ x' ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](html_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-6-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: [^1]: You can install it with: ```{.r} install.packages("ggplot2") ```
